context:
<Summary source="https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/migrant-deaths-un-record-numbers-b2874335.html">
## Summary: "The most dangerous migrant routes in the world where deaths have surged" (*The Independent*, February 22, 2026)

### Key Statistics

- The UN's Missing Migrants Project (MMP) has recorded **81,540 deaths worldwide since 2014**, peaking in 2024 with **9,197 deaths**.
- Despite a slight decline in 2025, **January 2026 was the deadliest January on record**, with **713 lives lost** globally.
- The **Central Mediterranean route** (North Africa to Southern Europe) has killed at least **26,416 people over the last decade** — the deadliest single migration path.
- **At least 501 people** have died on the Central Mediterranean route in the **first weeks of 2026 alone**.
- Across **all three Mediterranean routes** (Central, Eastern, and Western), **567 migrants have been killed** in early 2026 — the highest comparable figure since records began; the second-closest year was 2015, with 427 deaths.
- Italy saw ~3,500 sea arrivals in January 2015 vs. fewer than **1,500 in January 2026**, suggesting the **death rate per crossing has increased**.

### Notable Incidents (Early 2026)
- **February 6**: 53 people died when a migrant boat capsized near the Libyan coast.
- **Late January**: Italian authorities estimated approximately **380 people may have drowned in a single week** during Cyclone Harry.

### IOM/MMP Spokesperson (Named Institutional Source)
- Attributes rising deaths partly to stricter enforcement pushing migrants toward **more remote and dangerous routes**.
- Warns that **aid budget cuts** are limiting humanitarian presence in hard-to-reach areas, likely making death counts **even more of an underestimate**.
- Notes departures now originate as far south as **the Gambia**, involving weeks-long ocean journeys on fishing boats.

### Other Named Sources
- **Steve Valdez-Symonds** (Amnesty UK): Deterrence policies increase reliance on smugglers and cause more harm without stopping migration.
- **Lora Pappa** (Metadrasi, Greece): Greece's temporary asylum ban did not reduce arrivals — monthly boat arrivals *increased* from an average of 3,182 to 4,058 during the ban.
- **Ruvendrini Menikdiwela** (UNHCR): Called the figures a "huge and growing concern," urging states to uphold asylum commitments and improve search and rescue.
- **Diane Abbott** (UK MP): Argued governments need to make it easier for migrants to arrive legally.

### Contextual Note
The article's figure of **567 Mediterranean deaths** across all three routes by approximately mid-to-late February 2026 is particularly relevant to the forecasting question, given the question's threshold of **900 deaths by end of March 2026**.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.vaticannews.va/en/world/news/2026-02/thousands-feared-missing-mediterranean-migrant-tragedy.html">
## Summary: Nearly 1,000 Feared Missing in Mediterranean Migrant Tragedy (Vatican News, Feb. 3, 2026)

### Key Facts & Statistics
- **Up to 1,000 migrants** are feared dead or missing in the central Mediterranean following **Cyclone Harry**, based on survivor testimonies and official alerts compiled by Italian NGO **Mediterranea Saving Humans**
- **At least 380 people** were officially reported missing at sea as of **January 24**, according to Rome's Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre — the last official communication issued by European maritime authorities
- Cyclone Harry produced **waves over 7 meters high** and **winds exceeding 54 knots**
- Multiple boats departed from the Tunisian city of **Sfax** during the storm; one smuggler reportedly sent out **five convoys of 50–55 passengers each**
- Only **one boat** is confirmed to have reached Lampedusa (on January 22nd), with a deceased person on board; **1-year-old twins** were reported missing at sea
- **Maltese authorities** have recently recovered **a considerable number of bodies**

### Named Source Opinions
- **Laura Marmorale** (president, Mediterranea Saving Humans): Strongly condemned Italian and Maltese authorities for inadequate search-and-rescue response during the extreme weather event
- Humanitarian actors broadly characterized the situation as an **"unprecedented tragedy"**, calling for accountability and improved search-and-rescue operations

### Information Sourcing Note
- The 1,000 figure comes from **NGO estimates** based on testimonies from **Refugees in Libya** and **Refugees in Tunisia** networks — not from official government or IOM data, and thus carries uncertainty
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2026/2/22/eight-bodies-found-in-libya-and-greece-as-mediterranean-crossings-continue">
## Summary: Eight Bodies Recovered in Libya and Greece as Mediterranean Deaths Rise

### Key Incidents Reported
- **Libya**: Five bodies washed ashore near Qasr al-Akhyar, close to Tripoli. Victims described as "dark-skinned," including two women. A child's body was also briefly spotted before being reclaimed by the sea. Authorities expected more bodies to surface.
- **Greece (Crete)**: Three bodies recovered and at least 20 people rescued after a wooden boat capsized off Crete. Survivors were mostly Egyptian and Sudanese nationals, including four minors. Approximately 50 people were reportedly on board. The capsizing occurred when passengers attempted to climb ladders during a commercial ship rescue. A second boat carrying ~40 migrants was also spotted nearby.

### IOM & Broader Context (Named Sources)
- **IOM (February 9 report)**: ~53 migrants, including two babies, were dead or missing after a rubber boat capsized off Zuwara, Libya.
- **IOM (January figures)**: At least **375 migrants** reported dead or missing in January alone from multiple shipwrecks in the central Mediterranean, with hundreds more deaths believed unrecorded due to "invisible" shipwrecks.
- **UNHCR**: Over **16,770 asylum seekers** arrived in Crete in 2025; **107 people** died or went missing in Greek waters in 2025.
- **UN report (recent)**: Migrants in Libya face risks of killing, torture, rape, and slavery; called for a moratorium on returning migrant boats to Libya.

### Policy Context
- Greece suspended asylum application processing for three months in summer 2025 amid a surge in arrivals.
- Frontex is actively involved in search-and-rescue operations in the area.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.thenewhumanitarian.org/news/2025/10/24/gaza-aid-trickle-migrant-shipwreck-deaths-regime-change-venezuela-cheat-sheet">
## Summary of Article

**Disclaimer:** This article is a weekly humanitarian news roundup from what appears to be a humanitarian news outlet (likely *The New Humanitarian*). It covers multiple topics, only one of which is directly relevant to the forecasting question.

---

### Relevant Section: Mediterranean Migrant Deaths

The article reports on **deadly shipwrecks in the Mediterranean** and EU migration policy:

- **23 October incident:** More than **40 people drowned** when a migrant boat sank off the coast of Tunisia, described as "one of the deadliest incidents in the Mediterranean Sea this year." The Tunisian Coast Guard rescued 30 survivors.
- **17 October incident:** At least **20 people drowned** near the Italian island of Lampedusa. Eleven people were rescued by the Italian Coast Guard and a nearby merchant vessel.
- **UNHCR cumulative figure:** The UN's refugee agency has recorded **over 1,000 deaths in the central Mediterranean Sea** (between North Africa and Italy) so far this year (as of the article's publication, likely late October 2025).

The article also notes ongoing EU partnerships with North African authorities to curb Mediterranean crossings, and a legal filing with the ICC requesting investigation of 122 European leaders for alleged crimes against humanity related to EU migration policy.

---

*Other sections of the article cover Gaza aid, Venezuela, online speech and violence, Madagascar, and Afghanistan-Pakistan relations — not relevant to the forecasting question.*
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2026/02/12/2026-could-quickly-become-deadliest-year-for-migrants-crossing-the-mediterranean_6750405_4.html">
## Summary of Le Monde Article: "2026 could quickly become deadliest year for migrants crossing the Mediterranean"

**Note:** The article appears to be paywalled, with approximately 69% of the content unavailable. The summary below reflects only the visible portion.

### Key Facts & Statistics

- **January 1 – February 10, 2026:** At least **524 migrants died or went missing** across all Mediterranean routes in just 40 days.
- This is described as an **unprecedented death toll at this point in the year since IOM began recording deaths in 2014**.
- **Most recent tragedy cited (February 6, 2026):** 53 people died or went missing after a vessel carrying 55 migrants capsized off the **Libyan coast**.

### Comparative Data (Same Period in Prior Years)
| Year | Deaths (Jan 1 – Feb 10) | Annual Total |
|------|------------------------|--------------|
| 2025 | 219 | 1,873 |
| 2016 | 416 | 5,136 (deadliest year on record) |

### Named Source Opinions
- **IOM spokesperson** (to Le Monde): *"This is the worst start to a year we have seen in over a decade. Also the deadliest."*
- **Marino Dubois** (pseudonym, retired French woman tracking Mediterranean crossings via Facebook with 129,000+ followers): Describes the recent increase in shipwrecks as **"frightening."**
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://streamlinefeed.co.ke/news/mediterranean-tragedy-53-feared-dead-as-boat-capsizes-off-libya">
## Summary: Mediterranean Tragedy – 53 Feared Dead off Libya (February 9, 2026)

**Source:** Streamline Feed | **Date:** February 9, 2026

### Key Facts:
- At least **53 migrants are feared dead or missing** after a rubber dinghy capsized off the coast of **Libya, near Zuwara**
- The vessel departed from **Al-Zawiya** carrying **55 people** and sank approximately **six hours** into the journey
- Only **two survivors** — both Nigerian women — were rescued by **Libyan authorities**
- The survivors are receiving emergency medical care in **Tripoli**

### Survivor Testimonies:
- One survivor reported watching her **two babies drown** during the capsizing
- The other survivor lost her **husband** to the sea
- Both women described fleeing in search of a better life

### Broader Context (from IOM, cited in article):
- The **IOM** has described the Central Mediterranean as an **"invisible shipwreck,"** where hundreds of deaths go unrecorded
- The article frames this incident as part of a **recurring pattern** of migration disasters on this route

---
*Note: The article is from "Streamline Feed," a source of uncertain editorial standing. Core facts (survivor count, casualty figures, location) appear consistent with typical IOM-tracked incident reporting but should be cross-referenced with official IOM data.*
</Summary>

<Asknews_articles>
Query: Will the IOM Missing Migrants Project record at least 900 Mediterranean migrant deaths in 2026 before April 2026?
Here are the relevant news articles:

**The most dangerous migrant routes in the world where deaths have surged**
The UN's Missing Migrants Project (MMP) reports that 9,197 migrants and asylum-seekers died in 2024, the highest annual total since records began, with the first month of 2026 being the deadliest January on record, recording 713 deaths. The Central Mediterranean route from North Africa to Southern Europe remains the deadliest, with at least 26,416 deaths over the past decade and 501 fatalities in early 2026 alone. Overland migration from Afghanistan to Iran saw a 1,900% increase in deaths from 2019 to 2025 (65 to 1,323), and the route from western Africa to Spain's Canary Islands rose 480% (202 to 1,172). The International Organisation for Migration (IOM) attributes this surge to stricter border enforcement, which pushes migrants toward more remote, dangerous routes, often involving criminal smugglers. Drowning is the leading cause of death (46,686), followed by transport accidents (7,188), lack of basic needs (5,967), violence (5,891), and illness (3,418). Despite European governments' claims that strict policies deter migration, data shows such measures may increase risks: Greece's 2025 ban on asylum for North African arrivals led to a rise in boat arrivals from 3,182 to 4,058 monthly, and the UK's 2025 channel crossings reached 41,470, the second-highest on record. Campaigners, including Amnesty UK and Greek NGO Metadrasi, argue that deterrence policies are ineffective and inhumane, increasing reliance on smugglers and endangering lives. UNHCR’s Ruvendrini Menikdiwela emphasized the need for safer pathways, search and rescue operations, asylum access, and support closer to home, noting that the actual death toll may be significantly higher due to 'invisible shipwrecks' and underfunded monitoring. The MMP warns that aid cuts hinder accurate reporting, with mummified remains sometimes washing ashore in distant regions like Brazil.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 22, 2026 11:10 AM
Source:[The Independent](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/migrant-deaths-un-record-numbers-b2874335.html)

**Migrant Boat Capsizes Off Crete: At Least Three Dead, Search Continues**
At least three people died when a migrant boat capsized off the southern coast of Crete, according to the Greek port police, who reported the incident occurred on Friday, February 21, 2026. Around 50 migrants were on board, primarily from Egypt and Sudan, including four minors, as reported by the Greek news agency ANA. Twenty survivors were rescued by a merchant ship in the waters near Kaloi Limenes, just as the vessel—sent by the Greek Maritime Rescue Coordination Center—approached the overcrowded wooden boat. The capsizing occurred when passengers attempted to climb the ship’s ladders, and a sudden movement on one side caused the boat to overturn. Search operations continued on Saturday, February 22, 2026, with four patrol boats, one aircraft, and two vessels from the European Border and Coast Guard Agency (Frontex). A second boat carrying approximately 40 migrants was also discovered in the area, prompting an additional rescue mission. Since over a year ago, increasing numbers of migrants have attempted to reach Crete from Libya, which serves as a gateway into the European Union. However, the journey remains perilous: according to the UNHCR, over 16,770 asylum seekers arrived in Crete in 2025—more than on any other Aegean island. The UNHCR recorded 107 deaths or missing persons in Greek waters during 2025.
Original language: de
Publish date: February 22, 2026 09:36 AM
Source:[AFP](http://doc.afp.com/98FU6NT)

**Tragedy in the Mediterranean: Bodies Recovered in Libya and Capsizing Near Crete with Dozens Missing**
Two separate maritime tragedies occurred in the Mediterranean: five bodies were recovered on the Libyan coast near Qasr al-Akhyar, close to Tripoli, with additional victims possibly still being washed ashore; and a wooden boat capsized during a rescue operation south of Crete, resulting in confirmed deaths, dozens of missing persons, and several survivors rescued. The victims in Libya included two women and possibly a child, with preliminary medical-legal assessments indicating features consistent with dark-skinned migrants. The incident near Crete involved approximately 50 people on board, mostly Egyptian and Sudanese nationals, including minors, and occurred during a rescue operation involving commercial vessels and the Greek coast guard, which led to instability due to overcrowding on one side of the boat. Authorities reported conflicting numbers—some citing three recovered bodies, others up to five and about twenty missing—without official passenger lists. Search and rescue operations, coordinated by Greek maritime authorities and Frontex, continue with naval, aerial, and commercial vessel involvement. The situation underscores the extreme dangers of the central Mediterranean route, marked by overcrowded, unsafe vessels, human trafficking networks, and systemic abuse of migrants in Libya, as documented by the International Organization for Migration (IOM). The UNHCR reports over 16,770 asylum seekers landed in Crete by 2026, prompting temporary suspension of asylum processing and capacity expansion in Greek hotspots. International organizations and NGOs are urging stronger search-and-rescue mechanisms, political coordination, and structural solutions addressing root causes of migration, including local stabilization and legal pathways, amid ongoing calls for a halt to returns to Libya until safety conditions are restored. The events highlight persistent failures in humanitarian and political responses to migration crises.
Original language: it
Publish date: February 22, 2026 06:03 AM
Source:[Notizie.it](https://www.notizie.it/tragedia-nel-mediterraneo-corpi-in-libia-e-naufragio-vicino-a-creta-con-dispersi/)

**Boat capsizes off Crete, five dead and dozens feared missing**
A wooden boat carrying approximately 50 migrants capsized 15 nautical miles off Kala Limena on Crete's southern coast on February 21, 2026, resulting in at least five confirmed deaths and around 20 others missing, according to the Hellenic Coast Guard. The incident occurred when passengers shifted to one side while attempting to climb a ladder lowered from a rescue vessel, causing the overcrowded boat to lose balance. A Panamanian-flagged cargo ship rescued 20 survivors. Search and rescue operations, involving the Hellenic Coast Guard, Frontex, a helicopter, a military aircraft, and nearby commercial vessels, are ongoing. Three bodies were recovered initially, with two additional bodies found later. The event follows the earlier discovery of two men near the Evros River, believed to have died from hypothermia after crossing in freezing conditions. Greece has remained a major entry point for irregular migrants and refugees since 2015, with over one million arrivals recorded in the past decade. Frontex data indicates a 27% decline in irregular migration along the Eastern Mediterranean route in 2025, with approximately 51,400 arrivals in Greece last year.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 21, 2026 03:57 PM
Source:[D A I J I W O R L D](https://daijiworld.com/news/newsDisplay)

**At Least 3 Dead in Migrant Boat Capsizing Off the Coast of Crete**
At least three people died when a migrant boat capsized off the coast of Crete, Greece, on February 21, 2026, according to local media citing the Greek coast guard. The incident occurred approximately 15 nautical miles (nearly 28 kilometers) south of Kaloi Limenes in southern Crete. The victims are believed to be migrants attempting to reach the European Union from Libya. At least 20 people were rescued and brought safely to shore by a Greek rescue vessel. A search operation for possible missing persons is ongoing. Around the same time, another migrant boat carrying approximately 40 people was also detected nearby and its passengers were brought ashore together with the survivors. Human smugglers regularly transport migrants from Libya and Turkey to Crete and the Aegean islands. According to the UNHCR, about 42,000 migrants reached Greek islands by sea in 2025. In the eastern Mediterranean, 107 migrant deaths were recorded in 2025, though the Greek coast guard believes the actual number is higher due to unreported cases. A similar tragedy occurred weeks earlier when 15 migrants died in a collision between a Greek coast guard vessel and a speedboat near the island of Chios.
Original language: nl
Publish date: February 21, 2026 02:37 PM
Source:[vrtnws.be](https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/nl/2026/02/21/bootongeval-kreta-migranten-doden-vermisten/)

**Five dead, 20 missing after migrant boat capsizes south of Greece's Crete island - Yes Punjab News**
On February 21, 2026, a wooden migrant boat capsized approximately 15 nautical miles (27 km) south of Kala Limena on Crete’s southern coast, resulting in five confirmed deaths and at least 20 people missing. According to the Greek coast guard, the incident occurred when one of two commercial vessels dispatched by the national search and rescue center approached the overcrowded boat; as migrants scrambled to climb a ladder, the vessel tipped and capsized. A Panamanian-flagged cargo ship rescued 20 individuals, while Hellenic Coast Guard and Frontex vessels recovered three bodies, with two additional bodies found later at sea. Survivors reported around 50 people were on board, raising concerns that the death toll may rise. Search and rescue operations continue involving coast guard ships, commercial vessels, a helicopter, and a military aircraft. This incident follows the recovery of two migrant men near the Evros River border between Greece and Turkey earlier in February, believed to have died from hypothermia. Since 2015, Greece has served as a major EU entry point for irregular migrants and refugees, with over one million arrivals in the past decade; hundreds have died at sea and dozens in the Evros region. Frontex data shows a 27% decline in irregular migration flows through the Eastern Mediterranean route in 2025, with approximately 51,400 arrivals recorded in Greece that year.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 21, 2026 01:00 PM
Source:[YesPunjab – No.1 News-Portal. Latest News from Punjab, India & the World.](https://yespunjab.com/five-dead-20-missing-after-migrant-boat-capsizes-south-of-greeces-crete-island/)

**Ghost Shipwrecks: When the Sea Turns Against Migrants**
Following severe storms that hit southern Italy, the bodies of approximately 15 migrants were found along the coasts of Sicily and Calabria. Father Camillo Ripamonti, president of the Centro Astalli in Rome and head of the Jesuit Refugee Service, stated, 'It seems even the Mediterranean no longer wants to be complicit in these deaths.' According to the International Organization for Migration (IOM), at least 33,000 people—3,500 of them children or adolescents—have died since 2014 attempting to reach Europe across the Mediterranean Sea, with 78% of fatalities occurring along the central route, primarily from Libya to Italy. However, these figures do not account for 'ghost shipwrecks'—unwitnessed tragedies that vanish into oblivion. Evidence of such unrecorded deaths comes from families who have searched for missing relatives for years, often through the IOM’s 'Restoring Family Links' program.
Original language: it
Publish date: February 21, 2026 12:00 PM
Source:[L'Eco di Bergamo](https://www.ecodibergamo.it/stories/premium/Editoriale/naufragi-fantasma-se-il-mare-si-ribella-o_3675224_11/)

**Migrant charities call on Italy to ID dead washed ashore**
Italian migrant charities—including Memoria Mediterranea, the Association for Legal Studies on Immigration (ASGI), Mediterranea Saving Humans, and the European organization Alarm Phone—urged Italian authorities on February 20, 2026, to immediately initiate identification procedures for migrant bodies washed ashore along the Sicilian and Calabrian coasts following Cyclone Harry. The groups emphasized the urgent need to provide answers to families searching for loved ones, noting that approximately a dozen decomposed migrant bodies had been found on southern Italian beaches. According to reports from Mediterranea, Refugees in Libya, and Alarm Phone, over ten boats departed from Sfax, Tunisia, between January 14 and 21, 2026, carrying an estimated 1,000 people. Only one boat is known to have reached Lampedusa; the fate of the others remains unknown. Alarm Phone and Memoria Mediterranea have received numerous distress calls from families of missing migrants. The UN’s International Organization for Migration (IOM) reported that at least 567 migrant lives have been lost in the central Mediterranean so far in 2026.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 20, 2026 07:49 PM
Source:[AFP](http://doc.afp.com/98EF8NR)

**ONG Urges Italy and EU to Take Action to Recover Bodies in the Mediterranean**
The organization Mediterranean Saving Humans (ONG) has urged Italy and the European Union to implement measures to recover bodies from the Mediterranean Sea following the discovery of at least 13 corpses along the coasts of Sicily and Calabria in southern Italy over the past few weeks, after storms in January. During the storm 'Harry' between January 18 and 20, hundreds of migrants attempted to cross the Mediterranean from Tunisia under severe weather conditions. Initial estimates by the organization suggested around 380 people were missing, but this number may not reflect the full scale of the tragedy, as bodies continue to be found at sea or remain unaccounted for, particularly near Pantelleria (Sicily) and other southern Italian locations. The ONG called for effective identification procedures, timely information sharing with affected families, strengthened international cooperation, and the publication of updated statistics on victims. The International Organization for Migration (IOM) had previously warned at the end of January that hundreds of people may have died or gone missing due to shipwrecks caused by the storms. The IOM stated, 'Although the IOM is still awaiting official confirmation, the scale of reported fatalities points to another major tragedy in the central Mediterranean.' The central Mediterranean route, which connects North Africa—particularly Libya and Tunisia—to Europe, notably Italy and Malta, remains the world’s deadliest migration corridor. In 2025 alone, at least 1,340 people lost their lives attempting this crossing.
Original language: pt
Publish date: February 20, 2026 03:08 PM
Source:[Notícias ao Minuto](https://www.noticiasaominuto.com/mundo/2942615/ong-pede-a-italia-e-ue-medidas-para-recuperar-corpos-no-mediterraneo)

**Migrants: 1,000 Dead in Cyclone Harry, Families Demand Identification of Bodies**
Following the shipwrecks in the Strait of Sicily during Cyclone Harry between January 14 and 21, 2026, approximately 1,000 migrants are reported missing, according to humanitarian organizations. Mem.Med, Asgi, Mediterranea, and Alarm Phone have sent letters to national and local authorities urging the immediate activation of all procedures for the identification of bodies recovered along the Sicilian and Calabrian coasts. They demand full compliance with DNA collection protocols and guaranteed traceability of burials to provide answers to numerous families searching for their missing relatives. The exodus was triggered by escalating violence in Tunisia, prompting hundreds to depart from Sfax. Over ten boats reportedly left between January 14 and 21, carrying an estimated 1,000 people, during the two-week duration of Cyclone Harry, which severely disrupted weather conditions in the central Mediterranean, making navigation extremely hazardous and routes uncertain. According to Mediterranea, Refugees in Libya, and Alarm Phone, the number of vessels and people involved is consistent with the scale of the disaster.

**UN says 53 migrants dead or missing after boat sinks off Libya**
The International Organization for Migration (IOM) reported on February 10, 2026, that 53 migrants are dead or missing after a rubber boat carrying 55 people capsized off the Libyan coast near Zuwara on Friday, February 5, 2026. Two Nigerian women survived the incident and were rescued by Libyan authorities during a search-and-rescue operation. One survivor reported losing her husband, while the other said her two infant children died in the disaster. The IOM provided emergency medical assistance to the survivors. The agency emphasized that smuggling networks continue to exploit vulnerable migrants by deploying unseaworthy vessels, placing them at extreme risk. It called for enhanced international cooperation to dismantle these networks and expand safe, legal migration pathways. The IOM warned that hundreds may have died in 2026 attempting the dangerous Mediterranean crossing, especially under harsh winter conditions. According to its data, at least 375 migrants were reported dead or missing in January 2026 alone in the central Mediterranean, with many incidents unrecorded. The February 2026 sinking brings the total number of reported deaths or missing migrants on the central Mediterranean route in 2026 to at least 484. The IOM’s Missing Migrants Project also recorded over 1,300 migrants reported missing in the same region in 2025.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 10, 2026 12:56 PM
Source:[middleeastmonitor.com](https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20260210-un-says-53-migrants-dead-or-missing-after-boat-sinks-off-libya/)

**53 Migrants Dead or Missing After Boat Sinks Off Libya**
The International Organization for Migration (IOM) reported on February 9, 2026, that 53 migrants died or are missing after a boat capsized in the Mediterranean Sea off the coast of Libya. Two Nigerian women survived the incident, one of whom lost her husband and the other who said she 'lost her two infant children' in the disaster. The boat, carrying African migrants and refugees, departed from Zuwara, Libya, around 11:00 PM on February 5, 2026, and capsized after approximately six hours due to water ingress. Libyan authorities conducted a search and rescue operation but only rescued the two women. IOM teams provided emergency medical care to the survivors. According to the IOM, smuggling networks exploit migrants along the route from North Africa to Southern Europe, using unsafe, deteriorating boats and subjecting people to severe violations. The organization called for strengthened international cooperation, safe and orderly migration pathways, and efforts to combat smuggling networks. The IOM also warned that hundreds may have died since the beginning of 2026 amid harsh weather conditions. The European Commission reiterated its commitment to addressing root causes of irregular migration and supporting legal, safe, and organized migration routes. The IOM's Missing Migrants Project records that over 33,000 migrants have died or gone missing in the Mediterranean between early 2014 and late 2025, with 1,873 fatalities or disappearances in 2025 alone—1,342 of them in the central Mediterranean route.
Original language: ar
Publish date: February 09, 2026 12:34 PM
Source:[AFP](http://doc.afp.com/96ND8WF)

**53 Migrants, Including Two Infants, Die or Go Missing After Boat Capsizes Off Libya Coast**
The International Organization for Migration (IOM) reported that 53 migrants, including two infants, died or went missing after a rubber boat capsized off the coast of Libya on February 6, 2026. The boat, carrying 55 people, departed from Zuwara, Libya, around 11:00 PM on February 5, and capsized after approximately six hours due to water ingress. Only two Nigerian women were rescued during a search and rescue operation conducted by Libyan authorities; one reported losing her husband, and the other reported losing her two infants. The IOM expressed deep sorrow over the tragic incident and provided emergency medical care to the survivors in coordination with relevant authorities. According to IOM data, at least 375 migrants died or went missing in January 2026 alone due to unreported shipwrecks in the central Mediterranean amid harsh weather conditions, with estimates suggesting hundreds more deaths went undetected. The incident brings the total number of reported deaths or disappearances on this route in 2026 to at least 484, surpassing the 1,300 missing migrants recorded in the IOM’s Missing Migrants Project for 2025. The IOM warned that human trafficking and smuggling networks continue exploiting vulnerable migrants by using unsafe vessels, profiting from dangerous crossings, and exposing individuals to severe protection risks. The organization emphasized the urgent need for strengthened international cooperation, protection-centered responses, and the establishment of safe and orderly migration pathways to reduce risks and save lives.
Original language: ar
Publish date: February 09, 2026 11:47 AM
Source:[اليوم السابع](https://www.youm7.com/story/2026/2/9/53-%D9%85%D9%87%D8%A7%D8%AC%D8%B1%D8%A7-%D8%A8%D9%8A%D9%86%D9%87%D9%85-%D8%B1%D8%B6%D9%8A%D8%B9%D8%A7%D9%86-%D9%84%D9%82%D9%88%D8%A7-%D8%AD%D8%AA%D9%81%D9%87%D9%85-%D8%A3%D9%88-%D9%81%D9%82%D8%AF%D9%88%D8%A7-%D8%A8%D8%B9%D8%AF-%D8%BA%D8%B1%D9%82/7299070)

**UN fears hundreds missing or dead in Mediterranean shipwrecks since start of 2026**
The International Organization for Migration (IOM) warned on January 26, 2026, that hundreds of migrants may be missing or dead following multiple deadly shipwrecks in the central Mediterranean over the past 10 days. Preliminary reports indicate at least three shipwrecks occurred on January 23 and 25, with potentially 104 deaths confirmed or feared. Boats believed to have departed from Tunisia and Libya were involved, including one that left Sfax, Tunisia, carrying around 380 people between January 14 and 21. Survivors reported that another boat from the same location and time never arrived. In a confirmed search and rescue operation, three deaths were confirmed in Lampedusa, Italy, including twin girls aged approximately one year who died of hypothermia, along with one adult male who also died of hypothermia. The IOM stressed that smuggling migrants on unseaworthy and overcrowded vessels is a criminal act, particularly egregious given that severe weather, including Cyclone Harry, hampered rescue efforts. The agency described the situation as 'yet another major tragedy' and emphasized that the Central Mediterranean remains the deadliest migration route, with 1,340 fatalities recorded in 2025 alone and over 33,000 deaths or disappearances since 2014, according to the Missing Migrants Project. The IOM called for intensified international action to dismantle smuggling networks and prevent further loss of life.

**UN Agency: Mediterranean Sea Claims Hundreds of Migrants in Weeks**
The International Organization for Migration (IOM), a UN agency, reported on January 26, 2026, that hundreds of migrants are believed to have gone missing or died in the central Mediterranean Sea during January 2026, due to multiple boat sinkings. The organization expressed 'grave concern' over reports of several boat accidents, citing severe weather conditions that severely hampered search and rescue operations. According to IOM spokesperson Jorge Galindo, three boat incidents were reported in the past ten days—two on January 23 and one on January 25—resulting in the presumed deaths of 104 people. The IOM estimates that nine boats, primarily departing from Tunisia and Libya, sank between January 14 and 21, with approximately 380 people missing. Merna Abdel Azim, a data analyst with the IOM’s 'Missing Migrants Project,' confirmed that only three fatalities from the January 23 incident have been verified. Among the victims were twin infants, aged one, who died of hypothermia before reaching Lampedusa, Italy, and a man who died upon arrival under the same cause. The mother, a woman from Guinea, had boarded the boat in Sfax, Tunisia. The IOM warned that the final death toll could be significantly higher, underscoring that the central Mediterranean remains the world’s deadliest migration route. One additional boat, carrying at least 51 people, departed from the same location but never reached its destination and is believed to have sunk near Tobruk, Libya. Another boat with at least 51 people sank, with only one survivor. The IOM condemned the smuggling of migrants on unsafe, overcrowded vessels as criminal, emphasizing that organizing departures during severe storms constitutes a particularly heinous act, deliberately placing lives at near-certain risk. The organization reiterated that the central Mediterranean is the world’s most dangerous migration route, with 1,340 deaths recorded in 2025. Since 2014, over 33,000 migrants have died or gone missing in the Mediterranean, according to the Missing Migrants Project.

**Hundreds of Migrants Missing in Central Mediterranean in January 2026 (UN)**
The International Organization for Migration (IOM), a United Nations agency, reported on January 26, 2026, that hundreds of migrants likely went missing or died in the central Mediterranean Sea during January 2026 due to multiple boat sinkings. The IOM expressed 'grave concern' over reports of several boat accidents, citing severe weather conditions that severely hampered search and rescue operations. The organization is investigating these incidents and estimates that around 380 people may have gone missing in the first weeks of 2026 alone. According to IOM data, nine boats—originating from Tunisia—sank between January 14 and 21, 2026, carrying an estimated 380 migrants. Of these, only three deaths were confirmed, including twin infants who died from hypothermia before reaching land, and a man who died upon arrival. Survivors reported another boat with at least 51 people that vanished near Tobruk, Libya, and a separate boat with at least 51 people that sank, leaving only one survivor. **UN: Hundreds of migrants feared dead in shipwrecks since start of 2026**
The International Organisation for Migration (IOM) reported that hundreds of migrants may be missing or feared dead following multiple shipwrecks in the Central Mediterranean between January 14 and 25, 2026. The agency confirmed three deaths in Lampedusa, Italy, including twin girls aged about one year who died of hypothermia, and a man who also succumbed to cold. Preliminary reports indicate at least 104 deaths from three shipwrecks on January 23 and 25, involving boats believed to have departed from Tunisia and Libya. IOM is investigating nine additional missing boats that left Tunisia between January 14 and 21, carrying approximately 380 people. Severe weather from Cyclone Harry hampered search and rescue operations. The IOM warned that these incidents, occurring amid a major storm, point to a 'major tragedy' and underscore the lethal risks posed by smuggling networks that deploy unseaworthy, overcrowded vessels. The agency emphasized that sending migrants to sea under such conditions constitutes a criminal act, especially when weather warnings were known. The Central Mediterranean remains the deadliest migration corridor globally, with 1,340 fatalities recorded in 2025 alone. Since 2014, over 33,000 migrants have died or gone missing in the Mediterranean, according to the IOM's Missing Migrants Project.

**IOM calls for enhanced safety after 40 migrants drown in Tunisia shipwreck**
The International Organization for Migration (IOM) has called for enhanced safety measures following a shipwreck in Tunisia that resulted in the deaths of 40 migrants. According to IOM’s Missing Migrants Project, 1,000 deaths and disappearances have been recorded in the Central Mediterranean so far in 2025. The IOM reiterated its support for protection-sensitive search and rescue operations along key migration routes and urged the expansion of safe and regular migration pathways. The organization expressed 'deepest condolences to the families of the victims.' Migrants often endure extreme dangers during Mediterranean crossings, only to face European border protection measures, including expulsions, and eventual return to countries like Libya and Tunisia—nations that enforce Europe’s migration crackdowns in exchange for continued financial support. This system has drawn previous criticism, with some describing it as condemned due to its humanitarian consequences.
